title: How to Clean & Remove Stains from White Wood Furniture

steps.title: Dust the furniture with a soft, lint-free or microfiber cloth.
steps.content: Dust the furniture with a soft, lint-free or microfiber cloth . Dust shows up easily on white wood, making it look dingy and grimy. Fortunately, all you have to do is go over your furniture with a soft, lint-free cloth once a week. For extra dusty furniture, slightly dampen the cloth to prevent dust from circulating in the air. [1] X Research source Opt for a dusting cloth instead of a feather duster. Cloths work better for removing dust and they’re also less likely to scratch up your furniture. [2] X Research source Maintenance tip: Aim to dust your white wood furniture weekly to keep everyday dust from accumulating too much.

steps.title: Wipe away dirt with warm water and dish soap.
steps.content: Wipe away dirt with warm water and dish soap. This is the safest and easiest way to clean most wood, and white wood furniture is no exception. Fill a bucket with warm water and a squirt of mild dish soap. Dip a corner of a clean microfiber cloth or soft kitchen sponge into the sudsy water, then wring it out so it’s damp (not dripping). Gently wipe down the surface of your wood furniture. [3] X Research source Alternatively, use a 2:1 ratio of water and white distilled vinegar in place of dish soap. If you’re washing something treated with high-gloss or semi-gloss paint, like a kitchen cabinet, it’s okay to scrub a little. However, be gentle with more delicate finishes like whitewash, matte paint, or clear varnish. Wipe the wood lightly instead of scrubbing. [4] X Research source If you’re not sure how the finish will hold up to soap and water, put a drop of dish soap on a moist cotton ball. Gently rub the cotton ball on the furniture in an inconspicuous spot to make sure there’s no damage before proceeding. If the soap damages the finish in your test spot, continue with plain water instead.

steps.title: Remove soap residue with a damp, lint-free cloth.
steps.content: Remove soap residue with a damp, lint-free cloth. The last thing you want is to leave icky soap streaks on your furniture. To get all the remaining soap or vinegar off, dip an unused cleaning cloth or sponge in a bucket of fresh, clean water. Squeeze out most of the moisture, then gently buff residue away using circular motions. [5] X Research source You might need to wipe down the item a couple of times to get all the soap off.

steps.title: Dry your furniture thoroughly with a soft microfiber or lint-free towel.
steps.content: Dry your furniture thoroughly with a soft microfiber or lint-free towel. Lots of moisture is bad news for wood, especially if it has a delicate finish that water can easily seep through. To keep your white furniture in good shape, always dry it carefully after you’re done cleaning it. Wipe it down with a soft, clean, lint-free towel using light, circular motions. [6] X Research source Avoid using lots of water when you’re cleaning any type of wood furniture. Always use a cleaning cloth or sponge that’s only lightly damp, not sopping wet. Maintenance tip: Wipe down and dry your white wood furniture about once a month (or whenever you notice stains or dirt) to keep it looking its best.

steps.title: Brighten clear finishes with mineral spirits if the furniture looks dingy.
steps.content: Brighten clear finishes with mineral spirits if the furniture looks dingy. Mineral spirits are great for cleaning wood furniture and restoring its shine. If you have unpainted wood furniture with a clear finish (such as lacquer, shellac, varnish, or polyurethane), wipe it down with a soft cloth dipped in mineral spirits. Use gentle, circular motions until the cloth picks up no more grime. When you’re done, buff the furniture a second time with a clean, dry cloth to remove all the mineral spirits. [7] X Research source Mineral spirits can damage some finishes, such as paint. If you’re not sure whether mineral spirits will harm your furniture, test it in an inconspicuous spot first. This is a good option for unpainted furniture made from naturally white wood, such as holly, or bleached or whitewashed wood coated with a clear finish.

steps.title: Clean up grease stains with dish soap and water.
steps.content: Clean up grease stains with dish soap and water. Tackle most oil and grease stains on white wood furniture just like you would any other type of dirt—with a bit of dish soap and water. Soaps specially formulated for wood, such as Murphy’s Oil Soap , will also do the trick. [8] X Research source Gently wipe the spot with a cloth or sponge dipped in soapy water, then wipe away any soap residue with a second cloth dampened in clean water. Don’t forget to wipe the area dry when you’re done. Alternatively, try using a damp cloth sprinkled with baking soda or undiluted white distilled vinegar to cut through grease and oily residue.

steps.title: Banish marker stains with rubbing alcohol.
steps.content: Banish marker stains with rubbing alcohol. If your toddler has been scribbling on your favorite white dresser, don’t panic. A little alcohol will usually clean it right up. Moisten a cotton ball or makeup pad with rubbing alcohol and gently dab it on the stain to lift out the ink. Let the alcohol sit for a few minutes, then wipe it away with a clean, damp cloth. [9] X Research source Try not to scrub, since you could spread the stain around or damage the finish on the wood. Always test the alcohol in a hidden spot if you’re not sure how it will affect your furniture.

steps.title: Get ink stains out with toothpaste mixed with baking soda.
steps.content: Get ink stains out with toothpaste mixed with baking soda. You can also try gently buffing out ink or marker stains with baking soda-based, non-gel toothpaste on a soft cotton pad. Wipe in the direction of the wood grain and let the toothpaste sit for 2 minutes. Then, wipe the area with a damp cloth when you’re done. [10] X Research source You can buy baking soda-based toothpastes at most drugstores. However, if you can’t find it, just mix a little baking soda into a white, non-gel toothpaste to create your own. Some people also claim that toothpaste can brighten yellow spots on white furniture.

steps.title: Kill surface mold with distilled white vinegar.
steps.content: Kill surface mold with distilled white vinegar. If your white furniture has a little mildew on it, you might be able to clean it away with soap and water. However, for serious infestations, white vinegar can help. Mix equal parts vinegar and warm water in a spray bottle and spritz it on the area with the mold. Let it sit for an hour before wiping it away with a rag dampened in clean water. Dry the area thoroughly when you’re done. [11] X Research source For really stubborn mold, try scrubbing the area with a solution of 1 tablespoon (26 g) of Borax and 1 cup (240 mL) of water and a soft-bristle brush. Don’t wipe or rinse the solution away—just let it air dry, or use a dehumidifier to speed the drying process. Unfortunately, even diluted vinegar can dull or damage some paints or wood finishes. It might be necessary to repaint or refinish the affected area after treating the mold. For severe mold infestations, you may need to sand down the wood or even replace the damaged sections of your furniture. Safety tip: Wear rubber gloves, goggles, and a face mask to avoid inhaling mold spores. Do not clean mold yourself if it’s toxic black mold or takes up an area larger than 10 square feet (0.9 square meters).

steps.title: Remove water rings on unpainted white wood with a hair dryer.
steps.content: Remove water rings on unpainted white wood with a hair dryer. Water can stain unpainted wood, especially if your furniture has a clear finish. Fortunately, it’s usually pretty easy to get those stains out. Aim a hairdryer set on low at the stained area, gently moving the stream of air around to avoid overheating the wood. The stain should fade after a few minutes. [12] X Research source If that doesn’t work, try one of these options: [13] X Research source Gently buff the stain with a dab of mayonnaise or petroleum jelly. If the stain is stubborn, let the mayo or petroleum jelly sit on the spot for a few hours or even overnight before wiping it away. Use a soft cloth to rub a little white, non-gel toothpaste into the stain, moving with the grain of the wood. Wipe the paste away with a damp cloth when you’re done, then dry the area. For set-in water stains, put a few drops of lemon oil on the area. Then, carefully rub the stain with very fine grade steel wool, moving in the direction of the wood grain. You can also buy commercial water stain removers . Always test these products in an inconspicuous area first.

steps.title: Brighten oil-based white paints with sunlight.
steps.content: Brighten oil-based white paints with sunlight. While you might have heard that too much light can cause white furniture to yellow, the opposite is true in some cases. If your white furniture is finished with an oil-based paint, put it in a well-lit or sunny area to reverse any yellowing and restore it to its former glory. [14] X Research source If you can’t put your furniture in a sunny spot, artificial light will work as well. Place a lamp near the item and leave it on during the day to keep the area well lit. Oil-based paints may yellow without regular exposure to light, which helps break down compounds in the paint that can yellow over time. On the other hand, sunlight can cause some types of wood or wood finishes to darken or become yellow. If you’re not sure how light will affect your furniture, consult a wood repair or restoration expert for advice. Maintenance tip: Try to arrange white furniture with any other type of paint or finish away from areas with prolonged exposure to direct sunlight (like near windows), since this can contribute to yellowing over time.

steps.title: Clean off yellow stains with trisodium phosphate.
steps.content: Clean off yellow stains with trisodium phosphate . Trisodium phosphate, or TSP, is an alkaline cleaner that can remove many types of stubborn stains and dirt. If your painted white furniture has yellowed due to exposure to grease, cigarette smoke, or cooking fumes, try cleaning it with TSP. Dissolve ¼ of a cup (150 g) of TSP in 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water, then dip a sponge or cloth into the solution and wring out the excess moisture. Gently wipe the stained area with the solution, then wipe it dry with a clean cloth. [15] X Research source Safety tip: TSP can irritate your eyes and skin. Wear gloves, long sleeves and pants, and safety goggles while cleaning with TSP. Consider a respirator mask while working with dry TSP to avoid inhaling any of the powder. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Fix dings and scratches with a white wood touchup marker.
steps.content: Fix dings and scratches with a white wood touchup marker . No matter how careful you are, the finish on your white wood furniture can sometimes get scratched or chipped. If this happens, don’t worry. Touch up those little flaws with a wood repair marker. These markers come in a wide range of colors, including white and off-white. Simply color over the scratch with the marker to hide it. [17] X Research source You can purchase wood repair markers online or from a hardware or home supply store.

steps.title: Brighten stained or darkened pieces with wood bleach.
steps.content: Brighten stained or darkened pieces with wood bleach. Wood bleach can both lift stains and brighten the natural color of the wood. [18] X Expert Source Cleanzen Cleaning Services Residential Cleaning Specialists Expert Interview. 4 February 2022. Before bleaching the wood , you’ll need to strip off any finishes or coatings on the wood. Then, apply a commercial wood bleach such as two-part bleach or oxalic acid according to the directions on the package. Follow the safety instructions carefully to avoid hurting yourself or damaging the wood. [19] X Research source If the wood is already raw, clean it thoroughly with a rag dipped in water or mineral spirits before applying the bleach. Always work in a well-ventilated space and wear protective equipment, such as safety goggles and gloves, when using any type of wood bleach. You may need to neutralize some types of bleach with a second solution, such as a 50:50 mix of white vinegar and water. [20] X Expert Source Cleanzen Cleaning Services Residential Cleaning Specialists Expert Interview. 4 February 2022. Consult the product’s directions for instructions. Rinse the bleached wood thoroughly with warm water when you’re done, and allow it to air dry completely before adding any new paints or finishes. [21] X Expert Source Cleanzen Cleaning Services Residential Cleaning Specialists Expert Interview. 4 February 2022.

steps.title: Repaint or refinish badly stained or yellowed white wood.
steps.content: Repaint or refinish badly stained or yellowed white wood. If the paint or finish on your furniture is badly stained or yellowed, you can always touch it up or repaint it altogether. If the item is already painted, simply clean it, then add a coat of primer before repainting. Choose a water-based white paint to avoid problems with yellowing. [22] X Research source Use a varnish remover or paint remover to strip off old paints and finishes before applying a new type of finish, such as whitewash, varnish, or liming wax. Follow the instructions on the package to make sure you are using the product correctly. In some cases, you may be able to simply chip away cracked, stained, or peeling paint with a paint scraper. Sand the area down, then touch it up with a fresh coat of paint that matches the original finish.
